channel.title: BBC News - Asia
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: UN condemns Taliban's brutal crackdown on protests
item.description: The United Nations says the Taliban used live ammunition, batons and whips on protesters, killing four.

item.title: Afghanistan: BBC catches up with Afghan journalist who fled Kabul
item.description: Wahida Faizi spoke to a reporter in August saying she feared the Taliban would kill her for her work.

item.title: Air India Express: Deadly plane crash blamed on human error
item.description: Failure to follow procedures contributed to last year's crash at Calicut airport, investigators say.

item.title: Hong Kong Tiananmen vigil organisers charged under national security law
item.description: Three members of a pro-democracy group appeared in court on Friday charged with subversion.

item.title: US Biden and China's Xi hold first call in seven months
item.description: The two agree competition must not "veer into conflict" in their second call since Biden took office.

item.title: Afghanistan: First foreigners fly out of Kabul since US pull-out
item.description: Dozens of people, including 13 UK citizens, take a plane from Kabul to Qatar's capital Doha.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani: 'I apologise that I could not make it end differently'
item.description: Ashraf Ghani, who has sought refuge in the UAE, says he left Kabul to avoid "horrific" violence.

item.title: Afghanistan: A new order begins under the Taliban's governance
item.description: The Taliban's new ministers have taken office - but are they any different this time around?

item.title: Japan withdraw as Club World Cup hosts
item.description: Japan pulls out of hosting the Club World Cup in December because of Covid-19 restrictions in the country.

item.title: North Korea: Military parade features hazmat suits, gas masks
item.description: Their inclusion may be a sign that a special force was created to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Covid: Sydney reveals plan to end months-long lockdown
item.description: Australia's biggest city is likely to exit lockdown from next month, provided vaccinations continue.

item.title: Australia may cancel Afghanistan Test if women banned
item.description: Cricket Australia (CA) will cancel its men's Test match with Afghanistan if reports that the women's team cannot play under Taliban rule are true.

item.title: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte to stand as vice-president
item.description: Rivals accuse the president, barred from a second term, of seeking to cling on to power.

item.title: Why is there a food emergency in Sri Lanka?
item.description: With a weak economy and worsening Covid-19 situation, a food emergency has been declared in the country.

item.title: Crazy love: Behind China's crackdown on K-pop and other fan clubs
item.description: Chinese authorities have made it clear that they are not tolerant of overzealous celebrity fans.

item.title: Afghanistan: Women beaten for demanding their rights
item.description: Women in Afghanistan demanding their rights say they have been beaten by the Taliban.

item.title: Afghanistan: Could Pakistani drones hit the Panjshir Valley?
item.description: There are claims that Pakistan has used drones against anti-Taliban forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistanâ€™s government unravelled.

item.title: Australian bush rescue: Mother's reunion with boy lost for four days
item.description: Three-year-old Anthony "AJ" Elfalak is recovering with family after going missing for four days.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Sunil Perera: Sri Lanka's larger than life music legend dies at 68
item.description: Sunil Perera was the frontman of The Gypsies - Sri Lanka's biggest musical franchise.

item.title: What election losers tell us about Indian democracy
item.description: Thousands of parties contest Indian polls but the rising participation masks a murky underbelly.

item.title: Joe Ferrari: The high-rolling life of Thailand's controversial ex-police chief
item.description: Joe Ferrari, who is said to own 42 cars, was last month pictured torturing a suspect to death.

item.title: Saving Australian frog species on the brink of extinction
item.description: Scientists fear four species are already extinct but say urgent action can save others.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Why has Australia switched tack on Covid zero?
item.description: Australia is racing to vaccinate its population ahead of a huge shift in its pandemic strategy.

item.title: Afghanistan: What rise of Taliban means for Pakistan
item.description: Some Western powers hope that Pakistan could play a role as a mediator with the new Taliban government.
